segments.text: His small sports car let out a short growl as it left near Chen.
Its wheels were caked with mud that covered the entire farm area, making it look more like a strange off-road vehicle than a sports car.
Danny leaned back against the seat, feeling the fatigue that had accumulated in the last few hours during the complicated and lengthy calving.
but he was filled with satisfaction that he had finally helped the cow bring a cute and healthy calf into the world.
It took hours, and without realizing it, evening had come.
He dreamed of taking a good shower, letting the water wash away the fatigue and the barn smell that clung to him.
He had about half an hour of driving left until he reached the apartment the company rented after the pink house closed.
He had only recently returned to the Southern Settlement Circuit after a whole year up north.
The apartment housed a different on-call veterinarian each time, sometimes two together.
But it wasn't like the pink house that embraced you from the moment you entered, where you felt like you'd come home.
The apartment was somewhat spartan, and they grabbed something to eat on the way and only occasionally prepared light meals for themselves.
As if despite him, this apartment was located up the street from where the pink house stood.
Each time he passed by, he found himself slowing down a bit, trying to peer into the house through the branches of the wild-grown hedge, feeling his heart pinch.
He often wondered about the girl.
It had been so long since he heard from her, and he wanted to know she was OK.
Months before they left, he had already been up north and only managed to see Yosef once during a short visit.
But she wasn't there.

Just before her enlistment, in a burst of big brother emotion and concern, he wrote her a long letter trying to strengthen, encourage and comfort her through the tough days she was experiencing with the house's closure.
He remembered how the words poured deep from his heart straight onto the paper without lifting his head once until he finished.
Only then did he read it from start to finish and found himself with moist eyes.
Child, although I don't have your address in the army, I assume that whatever is still sent to the pink house will find its way to you.
After all, every postman in this land knows about the girl from the pink house and they will manage to find you if they just try a little.
I think of you many days, knowing that the recent period was hard and tumultuous to the soul.
Just the thought that you had to disconnect from this house forever and leave your life behind churns my stomach, and I can't imagine what it must do to you.
I need you to know that you always have a warm corner deep in my heart, and if you ever need anything, you can always turn to me, even just to talk and pour out your heart.
In recent years, I've seen you grow from a child into a girl and almost a young woman.
overcoming heartbreak after Lucy's passing, or at least managing to hide it so skillfully.
You know my heart broke too, with her departure.
She was like a mother and sister to me.
I saw you stand on your own two feet with all your talents, holding on to what remained of the house.
Raising Yosef a bit, forgiving his whims, trying to understand his heart while leaving the house proud of what it was.
Our soul talks made it clear to me that you tend to beautify things and always see the glass half full.
Probably growing up in a pink house develops great optimism in you, and you know how to color your life pink, certain that it will be okay.

You're a bit like a little sister to me, and a bit like a friend, and over the years when I wouldn't come for long periods, moving temporarily to take care of the cows and horses of the northern farmers,
or taking trips abroad, I always miss this embracing home, Lucy and Yosif, and of course, you.
I want you to know that you don't always have to paint everything pink.
Sometimes in life, you need to let the sadness and pain out.
Let it roll and drops on your cheek, maybe even burst into sobs.
When you build walls around pain, it can hote twice as much and eventually break out anyway.
Just at the wrong moment, wreaking havoc on the soul.
However, your optimism is a wonderful thing.
I have no doubt it will bring you new friends who will recognize your talents, your easy character, your mental strength, and the maturity that is very rare at such a young age.
You know I always told Lucy that you're provincial with a window to the big world.
And Yosef has a saying that describes you accurately as well.
He always says, I have a girl with common sense.
You're a girl who knows how to listen.
And of course, you know how to speak as well.
Sometimes you start telling me something and finish after a long hour.
Always things of taste.
And I, thinking it was a conversation, would realize it was you talking and me listening.
But every so often, when it was me explaining or telling you something, I noticed how well you knew how to listen.
How your blue eyes widened and filled with a serious and balanced expression.
How you tried to absorb everything you heard.
Take care of yourself, child.
See that those who seek your company are worthy of you.
Even if you feel homeless and destitute, always remember that your assets are who you are and they are many.
There is no flaw in you.

You're a rare and unique girl, a child that the pink house nurtured in culture, literature, poetry and music, in great freedom and independence, in love for people like for animals, all without materialism.
You possess simplicity and humility not mixed with shame, and indeed you should be proud of who and what you've grown to be.
This whole combination of wisdom with the human warmth you are blessed with will be the beacon on your path.
Trust yourself and your abilities.
I have no doubt that anyone who crosses your path will immediately see that you can do almost anything.
I know this period is also marked by financial constraint.
And perhaps it is good it finds you while in the army where most of your clothing and food are provided.
Yet still, if you have any urgent need, you must promise me that you will never hesitate to turn to me.
You can always rely on me and see me as a kind of big brother.
Life goes on and often brings surprises and experiences we never imagined.
Some are unpleasant, sometimes even difficult, but dealing with them depends on us and everything we are.
I know with certainty and clarity that you can handle everything the day will bring.
Do not worry, be calm and confident in yourself, and everything will settle down.
Even if many days pass without hearing from you, I would like to be by your side on your wedding day.
to see the one who will win your heart and know that he is worthy of you and knows how to keep your love.
Take care of yourself, child.
Be well.
Yours, Dee.
She never responded to his letter and he wondered if she even received it.
Now he passed by the house and the small car seemed to slow down on its own.
He lifted his head to peak and it seemed the wild grown hedge was now wrapping the house as if guarding it protectively.
He had almost passed the house, but suddenly pressed the brakes and stopped.
It seemed he saw a flicker of light from the small window above the corner chair.
He reversed, peaked again, and indeed a small light shone from that window.
In a burst of excitement, he turned the car and drove towards the alley, stopping at the house entrance.
He got out of the vehicle slowly with some hesitation, unsure of what he would find there.
Maybe someone had simply forgotten to turn off the light in the abandoned house.
He stood by the door, and instead of pushing it open, as he usually would, he placed a hesitant hand on the handle, unsure if it would open at all.
Slowly, he pressed it, and to his surprise, the door opened easily and quietly.
In the corner chair opposite him,
Under the lit lamp was the girl curled up, her legs tucked beneath her and a book in her hands.
For a brief moment, they stared at each other in astonishment, and within a minute she leaped towards him with sparkling eyes and hugged him warmly.
My goodness, she said, with a big smile, you brought the whole barn with you.
He laughed with her and reluctantly freed himself from.
Her embrace.
Despite their closeness, he didn't remember them ever hugging.
What are you doing here?
I didn't believe anyone was here when I saw the flicker of light in the window.
It's a long story, but first let me get you something to drink and eat.
And if I knew you had clean clothes in the car, I'd send you to shower first, because with all my love for you, this smell is simply unbearable.
She laughed heartily.
I do have a bag with clothes in the car, but are the rooms even open?
Yes, but that will wait for the long story.
She gave him a key to his usual room and watched him walk out.
She felt as if she had recovered from an illness, as if this Danny had momentarily healed her soul and filled her heart with a sense of family.
About half an hour later, he returned thoroughly clean, smelling of his watered down old spice and sat down at the table she'd set.
She quietly served him a home-cooked meal, like Lucy's, and sat down beside him.
Only then did she calmly begin to recount all her experiences since her enlistment.
The day she lost her pink house, Rolf loved her and returned to his distant country.
Joseph and his partner in their home, which felt foreign to her,
Zevik, the neighbor who coughed twice and passed away in his sleep.
And only then did she tell him about Yehuda and this fresh arrangement that for now provided her a home.
They sank into silence.
The story was hard for him to digest.
Could it be that the girl was a refugee in her own home?
He looked around and back at her.
The house looks as if Lucy popped by for a visit.
It hasn't been this well cared for in years.
Every picture in place.
Everything clean and shiny.
Even a vase of flowers on the table.
And the food.
So delicious.
I forgot she whispers to you.
I just hope you can be here undisturbed at least until the end of your service.
What's for sure is that I'm going to talk to the company about taking a room or two when needed and returning the apartment to the owners.
It's nicer here and you could earn a bit of money too.
You understand I'm only here on weekends and can only clean the rooms then.
I can leave you a key to the dining room but not for others.
And who do you think cleans the apartment?
A cleaner comes once a week.
This will be a great arrangement, and I could also operate the sprinklers from time to time.
A short while later, he drove and collected his few belongings from the apartment, arranging them in his room, placing everything in its usual spot.
feeling like he'd come home.
Only then did he return to the corner chair, giving her a book he'd finished so she could read a tradition they had kept.
They sat and talked about Yosef, his partner, about the feeling of loneliness, about the successful days in the army, and mostly about the little white lies and the secrets she kept to herself.
He knew her soul, understood her heart, knew her inside since she was a child.
He gave her good advice, calmed her down, and mostly made her feel that he respected what she had grown to be.
By then it was almost midnight, and fatigue overcame them.
They parted with a good night wish, and each went to their room.
She looked after him in wonder, almost not believing.
Feeling how that sense of family security, that feeling of healing, returned to flow in her.
